node.plaintext:
We're creating illustrations for developer concepts, catch phrases, and other
jargon. Yak shaving  is one of those terms. It's fun to dig into the concepts
and learn about their background, teach other people about them, and we get some
cool images to use in a number of different ways that aren't just company
branding. We have ideas for some new illustrations, we're happy to take other
suggestions and have people vote for their favourites
[https://talk.fission.codes/t/vote-for-and-suggest-developer-concepts-to-illustrate/590]
.

Bear and Penguin
We had fun last year sourcing the Bear and Penguin illustration for the Berlin
Open Source Salon [https://blog.fission.codes/bear-penguin-bounty-for-boss/].
The inner meaning here is that the bear is the coat of arms for the city of
Berlin – the "Berliner Bär". The bear is holding a Club Mate drink, traditional
drink of German hackers (although I know at one time the Mozilla Vancouver team
imported it for their office fridge, too!). And the penguin is the long time
mascot of Linux.

Wizards and Snakes
Since then, we've worked with Bruno Monts [https://www.behance.net/brunomonts],
an illustrator based in Brasil, to create a number of other illustrations.

We just released the Haskell Wizards  series, written up in our Haskell for
Typescript Devs book
[https://haskellfortypescriptdevs.fission.codes/appendix/haskell-wizards]:

SCREAMING SNAKE CASE [https://blog.fission.codes/screaming-snake-case/]  was
just a pure piece of fun, with the vaporwave stylings pushed to the max. We did
a first run of stickers with this image, and can't wait to come up with t-shirts
or other swag with this fun image:

Vote for developer jargon to illustrate
We're going to get some more illustrations made, and have a couple of ideas
already:

 1. Kebab case  wouldn't be vaporwave, but maybe a sort of comic / graphic art –
    a delicious kebab, dripping sauce.
 2. The Elm programming language  is a favourite of ours at Fission, so vote for
    this one if you want an Elm-y character in the style of the Haskell Wizards
 3. We recently added some definitions for Yak shaving to our forum
    [https://talk.fission.codes/t/yak-shaving-programming-term/582]. It's only
    about 20 years old – but of course software development has changed
    dramatically in the last 20 years, so it's a term that's not well known.
 4. Bike shedding  and
 5. Pets vs. Cattle are the last two suggestions we have so far.

Read more about these ideas, vote in the forum for your favourites to get
illustrated, or suggest your own »
[https://talk.fission.codes/t/vote-for-and-suggest-developer-concepts-to-illustrate/590]

We're working with Bruno now, and will run the vote for a couple of weeks, and
then get at least 2 or 3 of the developer jargon ideas turned into high quality
illustrations.

Post header photo by Lieve Ransijn
[https://unsplash.com/@lievemax?utm_source=unsplash&utm_medium=referral&utm_content=creditCopyText] 
 on Unsplash
[https://unsplash.com/s/photos/yak?utm_source=unsplash&utm_medium=referral&utm_content=creditCopyText]

node.plaintext:
Did you know that different programming languages and certain developer
preferences have led to different standards in naming functions, variables,
constants, and other programming terms?

Camel case (wikipedia [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Camel_case]) – or should I
say, camelCase – is probably the best known programming naming convention, in
either PascalCase  (initial capital) or dromedaryCase  versions.

While researching, we were delighted to learn about kebab-case-being-a-thing,
and you can find a bunch more letter cases on Wikipedia
[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Letter_case#Special_case_styles]. 

But we're here to tell you about snake_case:

> The use of underscores as word separators in identifiers in programming
languages is old, dating to the late 1960s. It is particularly associated with
C, being found in The C Programming Language
[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_C_Programming_Language]  (1978), and
contrasted with PascalCase [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pascal_case]  (a type
of camel case [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Camel_case]). However, the
convention traditionally had no specific name: the Python style guide refers to
it simply as "lower_case_with_underscores".

Within Usenet [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usenet]  the name "snake_case" was
first seen in the Ruby
[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ruby_(programming_language)]  community in 2004,
used by Gavin Kistner

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snake_case
This, of course, leads us to SCREAMING_SNAKE_CASE – all capitals, often used
when defining constants. 

And now, a vapourwave inspired illustration:

We're a developer focused company, which means we have fun with
developer-centric in jokes and illustration. We've made a first run of stickers
that you can either get in person at tomorrow's Drinks with Canadians in San
Francisco [https://blog.fission.codes/drinks-with-canadians-in-sf/], or fill out
your postal address on our swag signup page [https://swag.fission.codes]  and
we'll get some sent to you.

We've got some other programming related illustrations that will get turned into
stickers and other artwork lined up, with Haskell-related characters being up
next. Haskell also happens to be what we're writing our backend services in
[https://github.com/fission-suite/web-api].

The artist behind this first set of work is Bruno Monts, a freelance illustrator
and designer from Brazil. You can see his portfolio on Behance
[https://www.behance.net/brunomonts]. Thank you Bruno for your great work!

Stay tuned for more fun developer art!

Update August 20th:  We've got a dedicated Artwork page
[https://fission.codes/artwork]  for all the illustration that we've made.

You can visit the Fission Swag Shop [https://shop.fission.codes]  to buy
stickers and t-shirts, or buy a Screaming Snake Case t-shirt right here:

Camel case (wikipedia) – or should I say, camelCase – is probably the best known programming naming convention, in either PascalCase (initial capital) or dromedaryCase versions.

While researching, we were delighted to learn about kebab-case-being-a-thing, and you can find a bunch more letter cases on Wikipedia.

But we're here to tell you about snake_case:

The use of underscores as word separators in identifiers in programming languages is old, dating to the late 1960s. It is particularly associated with C, being found in The C Programming Language (1978), and contrasted with PascalCase (a type of camel case). However, the convention traditionally had no specific name: the Python style guide refers to it simply as "lower_case_with_underscores".

Within Usenet the name "snake_case" was first seen in the Ruby community in 2004, used by Gavin Kistner

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snake_case

This, of course, leads us to SCREAMING_SNAKE_CASE – all capitals, often used when defining constants.

We're a developer focused company, which means we have fun with developer-centric in jokes and illustration. The artist behind this first set of work is Bruno Monts, a freelance illustrator and designer from Brazil. You can see his portfolio on Behance. Thank you Bruno for your great work!
